description.text: Spool holder for 1 kg plastic spools from onlinefilament (and others). Set up to mount directly or atop the Filament Spool Stacker.

Print.
Mount atop Makerbot directly or on the Filament Spool Stacker. Slots in the bottom to allow insertion of mounting bolts. Alternately, the spool holder can be glued to Spool stacker. The original OpenSCAD file has been modified to make both parts. Set "doShaft = 1;" to create the new 1 kg spool holder, and set it to 0 to make the matching Filament Spool Stacker (to stack atop the original Makerbot Filament Spool Holder from charlespax thingiverse.com/thing:8762 )

This is a font of characters from the FreeSerif font distributed by the GNU FreeFont project.  The font is in the form of blocks similar to what would be used in a printing press.  The purpose of this font is to facilitate adding text to an object, especially in the Wings3D design software.  Block characters can be concatenated using the "Put On" command, followed by a "Weld" command to make them into a single object.  Then remove the lines between characters, and the whole text string can be welded to any simple surface.
Also see the FreeSans block typeset font, which contains additional instructions and comments: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286570
This is a motivator to always think out side the box.
For toy stables.
Print, put in toy stable for your toy horses

After a couple Earthquakes in the greater LA area I thought it would be a good idea to make up some clips I can screw into my Cherry china cabinet to keep it from falling over in the "Big one."  Just using some zip ties for now until I can get some 3/16" -1/4" rope to tie them together.

comments.text: I would be very interested to see if the 3d printed nubbin could withstand the force of a cabinet trying to fall over...  I would imagine it would, but youd have to print it pretty solid.

An art toy to be used to draw patterns on a paper. In the SketcUp file there are different sizes of the big inward gear. Update: A friend found the real name of the thing its a: Spirograph - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirograph
I didn't know that when I made it. :)

Print and enjoy. :)
The stl fits on a 140x140 Huxley bed.

comments.text:
Very nice and fun! That said, I don't think these are made with the right ratio of teeth.
When I used this as a kid, as you continue to move around the circle, it would continue to offset itself to make a pretty design. This doesn't happen with this set because the teeth ratios are evenly divisible.
For instance:
Main outer cog: 120 teeth
XL Cog: 50 teeth (divisible after 5 revolutions around the outer cog)
L Cog: 40 teeth (evenly divisible)
M Cog: 30 teeth (evenly divisible)
S Cog: 20 teeth (evenly divisible)
XS Cog: 15 teeth (evenly divisible)
comments.author: doohickey

comments.text: Correct, there would happen "more" if the teeth did not match. :) However, it was just made for fun and I did not calculate anything when making the gears. Just made them. :) It's good that it's easy enough to make your own gears. Just use the sketchup gear plugin and create the gear you want. :)
comments.author: doohickey

comments.text: Okay thanks, will try it out. I'll probably have to experiment a bit to find a good offset
comments.author: Snille

comments.text: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1376946
comments.author: 3DChannel

comments.text: What is the pitch and pressure angle for the gear models in this set?
comments.author: ApexDesign

comments.text: Pitch I don't remember. I basically left all at defaults in the plugin in SketchUp when I made the gears. I do know that the pressure angle is 20. :)
comments.author: ApexDesign

comments.text: I want another outside gear so I can get more variety from my existing set. Maybe a little smaller.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: There are two outside gears available in the SketchUp file. Then if you want you can use the Gear-plugin to create a new one at the size you want. Here you can find the gear plugin: http://www.ohyeahcad.com/download/http://www.ohyeahcad.com/downl... and if I remember correctly I used this formula "Teeth / 2 = Diameter". So if you want 100 teeth the diameter is 50mm. :) Pressure angle I left default (20.0)....
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: If I remember right, the original outer ring had holes for push pins such that the paper and ring could be fastened to a piece of cardboard.  This would help keep the center as different gears are used..
comments.author: bjbsquared

comments.text: i have played with this as a kid :) now i shall print it :D
comments.author: strangeloop

comments.text: I thought the SAME thing(:
comments.author: strangeloop

comments.text: Everytime I see a Spirograph I think of the quote from the simpsons.
comments.author: notstarman

comments.text: The original Spirograph gears had the holes laid out in a spiral, to maximize the number of variations available on each gear. It might be interesting to try to do that with these designs. Many thanks for bringing us the ability to tinker with the design ourselves.
comments.author: tadrow

comments.text: Technically called hypotrochoid or epitrochoid. I see you are using sketchup but if this was parametric...oh the possibilities!
comments.author: sirmakesalot

comments.text: Which software you are using for the gear design.
comments.author: brianhomer

comments.text: I'm using SketchUp with the gear-plugin from here: http://www.ohyeahcad.com/download/http://www.ohyeahcad.com/downl...
comments.author: brianhomer

comments.text: I'm attempting to print one right now.  My build platform is only 120x120 so I had to scale it down a bit.  Hoping it still works slightly smaller.
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: Even scaled down it seems to work pretty well.
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: Very cool. I used to spend a LOT of time with the Spirograph! It's cool that you invented it without knowing about the original.

comments.text: I agree! Here is a pat on the back for re-inventing it, it means you can come up with awesome ideas! pat :)

comments.text: very nice

description.text:
Useful add-on to guide your filament into the extruder from either a reel or even works with a roll on the floor. Clamps to the top two rails and assemble much like the Mendel Prusa with 8mm threaded rods, washers and nuts. The top guide spool spins freely and slides along the rail to suit the printer head.
I use this with a triangular frame reel stand behind the printer with three reels of PLA on it and it feeds really well from full or emptry drums.
In the photos attached you can see I am feeding PLA from a pile on the floor below the printer.

The rod tops are printed with 7mm holes so clean them out with a 7mm drill then tap them to M8 (or substitue the equivalent old-world imperial thread). The spool ends are printed at 8mm but will probably need a drill run through them. Other than that it's pretty much as it looks in the photos.
The top reel pushes together without the need for glue or machine screws. I designed it with holes for 3mm machine screws but they are not needed as it is a very snug fit.
The top bar clamp has holes for 3mm machine screws and I have used them to clamp it to the top bars. It may work without them as the vertical rods also secure the bottom clamp but I haven't tried it. 19 September - Redesigned the top rod clamps to click into place without bolts or screws. They leave room at the back for you wiring bundle too :)

Replacement base plate for Printrbot spool stand that's compatible with 1.75mm Colorfabb PLA spools.  
There are small impressions on the bottom of the base to add rubber feet into, to prevent the base from moving around while in use.

There is a small depression on the bottom to put rubber feet in to keep the printer from sliding around.

description.text: I saw the Makerbot Business Card Displayer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1050) and liked the design but wanted to add my own logos so I took the STL and used OpenSCAD to remove the logo and make a plain business card holder that can then be modified with any logo that you want. I used embossed instead of raised and have so far created a Microchip, K2L and FWB branded business card holders.
Use your favorite 3d design tool (my tool of choice is OpenSCAD) and add your desired logo/text raised/embossed as desired to the plain business card holder, print and enjoy!

A revision of the Sidecar Controller Housing for Beta Smoothieboard Taller & deeper to accomodate the larger footprint of the 5XC Kickstarter version of the Smoothieboard. Approx.222mm Tall x 104mm Wide x 134mm Deep Houses:
5XC Smoothieboard (oriented long dim. vertically)
ReprapDiscount GLCD
Diablotek PHD Series PHD380M 380W MicroAtx PS. Holes for the power switch, printer harness, usb cable are omitted from these models and left for the individual to define. This is a design of my own creation.

Hasn't been printed by me. but it's not much different from the original. The 4 spacers that are part of the top cover stl are for placement between the glcd circuit cards. A couple of pieces of music wire are used to pin the hinges together. Bond (superglue) the pins into the door. It will likely be necessary to drill out the holes in the hinges as they tend to close up during printing. The information on how to connect the GLCD to the Smoothieboard can be found at http://smoothieware.org/panel#toc3

comments.text: Yeah. I thought that was what you would say. And I agree, somebody needs to start making power supplies specifically for 3D printers.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:107494 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=107494

Using the following options: Diameter = 40
ValueHeight = 15
CasinoName = Stingray`s Poker Night
CasinofontName = write/Letters.dxf
CasinoNameHeight = 5
ValuefontName = write/Letters.dxf
width = 175
Thickness = 3.5
ChipValue = 50
This is a model of the 1960's Lincoln Continental Hood Emblem.

I liked the twisted star box (which is also parametric) but it requires not only Art of Illusion but also a special under development and undocumented MetaCADEvaluator plugin that is part of the development version of CSGEvaluator for Art of Illusion:  
objects.reprap.org/wiki/Builders/Metalab/AoI_CSG_Evaluator  
and since I wanted a box with very specific dimensions I decided to make a version using my tool of choice - OpenSCAD!  
File size < 3k instead of 12k!  :-)

There are three primary variables:

  • the inner radius (i.e. the size of the hole),

  • the wall Thickness (used for top, bottom and lip) and

  • the star box Height (the height of the box w/o the lip/top).
    • The remaining variables: sbLip, tFactor and tGap can be changed if desired. They are documented in the SCAD design file.

comments.text: what volume does this hold?
comments.author: hdemarzo

comments.text: It is parametric!

comments.text: I'm still printing mine, will post the final result when it's done. Your's is a lot smoother than mine. Mine has these lines that travel up diagonally through the whole box. But it's consistent... it's not random so i don't get why it's doing it.
